title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO — On a night where the scoreboard told a story of defensive dominance, one man authored a legend. Michael Jordan, in a performance for the ages, dropped 41 points on the Milwaukee Bucks, carrying the Chicago Bulls to an 84-62 victory in 1998.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Jordan’s stage. While the rest of the Bulls’ offense sputtered, His Airness was a study in relentless efficiency. He attacked the rim with ferocity, hit from mid-range with cold-blooded precision, and single-handedly outscored entire Milwaukee stretches. The Bucks, with no answer for number 23, watched helplessly as he piled up points against their best defensive efforts.

The rest of the game was a mere footnote to Jordan’s virtuoso show. Scottie Pippen, the other half of Chicago’s famed duo, contributed a quiet 10 points, content to feed the hot hand and lock down defensively. For the Bucks, Ray Allen led with a respectable 20 points, but his effort was drowned out by the Jordan-centric roar of the Chicago Stadium.

The final score, a lopsided 84-62 decision, was secondary. The real story was the 41 points beside Jordan’s name, another breathtaking chapter in his historic career. On this night, it wasn't about a team winning; it was about the greatest player on the planet putting on a masterclass, reminding everyone why he reigned supreme.
